repnme.cdata!: India - Second District Primary Education Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is rated satisfactory,
            with project sustainability likely. The overall performance
            of both the World Bank and the Borrower are rated
            satisfactory. The lessons from this project are innumerable
            due to the size and scope of the program, its development
            over time, and the nature of the relationships built among
            the central and state governments and development partners,
            including the Bank. Mostly, the lessons emerged regarding
            ownership, strengths of program design, the need to be
            flexible and learn from experience, staff continuity, the
            need for solid baseline data and a fully integrated system
            of monitoring and evaluation, and the need to deepen efforts
            for pedagogic change and capacity.

2851305.trustfund:
TF020916-DISTRICT PRIMARY EDUCATION
            PROGRAM II,TF022582-PHRD-SECOND DISTRICT PRIMARY EDUCATION,TF025500-PHRD-BASIC EDUCATION PROJECT,TF025520-PHRD-MATERNAL AND CHILD HEALTH

repnme.cdata!: Delivering universal primary education in India

abstracts.cdata!:
In a nation as sprawling and diverse as
            India, offering even a few years of education to all boys
            and girls is a daunting prospect, but one that the
            government is confronting with the aid of the international
            community. Initiated in the early 1990s, the district
            primary education program (DPEP) was designed to facilitate
            India's efforts to achieve universal primary education
            and it has since become the world's largest education
            program, reaching 60 million children. The project also aims
            to reduce the number of school dropouts and improve the
            overall quality of primary education Enrollment in general
            has increased, and in a three-year period enrollment of
            girls increased to 43 percent from 38 percent.
